1.content:
Q: Who was the only fictional character to feature in Time Magazine's 100 most important people of the 20th Century?
A: BART SIMPSON

Q: This quiz is printed on A4 paper which has a length of 297mm. How wide, in millimetres, is A4 paper?
A: 210

Q: How long do NFL football teams have to get a play off (the play clock)?
A: 40 Seconds

Q: John Chapter 11 Verse 35 is the shortest verse in the Bible. How many words make up the verse?
A: Two

Q: The 3rd of his vice presidents (after John Nance Garner and Henry Wallace), who took over the reins of power when FDR kicked off?
A: Harry Truman

Q: In April 1814 which King gained the French throne to begin the Bourbon Restoration?
A: LOUIS XVIII

Q: Which torture chamber was invented by George Orwell?
A: Room 101

Q: How many squares does a Rubik’s Cube have on each side?
A: 9

Q: The SS Titanic sank in which year?
A: 1912

Q: In 1984, in Bophal, India, there was a leak of 30 tons of methyl isocyanate, which resulted in the deaths of 25,000 people. What American chemical company owned the plant where the leak occurred?
A: Union Carbide

Q: Who had a No 1 in the 80's with Karma Chameleon
A: Culture Club

Q: Which Tim Burton film is the highest-grossing film of 2010 and, already, the fifth highest-grossing film of all time worldwide?
A: 'ALICE IN WONDERLAND'

Q: How many ‘E’ tiles are provided in a Scrabble game?
A: 12

Q: As at early 2015, how many Prime Ministers have served in Australia since 2013?
A: 3

Q: Which city in Georgia was burned by General Sherman during the American Civil War
A: Atlanta

Q: "Which detective is the protagonist of the novels ""Dead Man's Folly"", ""Cards on the Table"" and ""Mrs McGinty's Dead""?"
A: (Hercule) Poirot

Q: How many feet are in a furlong?
A: 660

Q: In years and days, how old was Luigina Giavotti when she won a silver medal in gymnastics in 1928, and is still the youngest medal winner today?
A: 11 years and 302 days

Q: Which American naval destroyer was attacked in Aden in October 2000?
A: U.S.S. COLE

Q: From around 2566 B.C. to 1311 A.D. what was the world’s tallest building?
A: Great Pyramid of Giza

Q: Which British fashion designer was commissioned by Stanley Kubrick to design the costumes for the film ‘2001: A Space Odyssey’?
A: Hardy Amies

Q: What is commonly known as the 'sport of kings'?
A: Horse Racing

Q: Which is the largest city in Scandinavia by population ?
A: STOCKHOLM

Q: Cable News Network (CNN), the first channel to provide 24-hour television news coverage, was founded by Ted Turner in what year?
A: 1980
